title: 104_hr925
content:
The "Private Property Protection Act of 1995" ensures that no law or agency action should diminish the value of privately owned property. Federal agencies must exercise authority to prevent such limitations and property owners have the right to compensation. The Federal Government must compensate property owners if an agency action limits property use, reducing its value by 20% or more. Compensation equals the value decrease caused by the action. If the value diminishes by over 50%, the owner can choose to sell that portion at fair market value. The Federal Government must compensate property owners if an agency action limits property use, reducing its value by 20% or more. If the value diminishes by over 50%, the owner can choose to sell that portion at fair market value. Property with compensated limitations cannot be used contrary to the agency action, unless the owner refunds the compensation amount adjusted for inflation to the Treasury. The Act states that if a use is considered a nuisance under State law or is already prohibited by a local zoning ordinance, no compensation will be provided for the limitation on that use. There are exceptions outlined in the Act as well. SEC. 5. EXCEPTIONS.

No compensation under this Act for agency actions to prevent hazard to health or safety, or damage to specific property. No compensation for agency actions under Federal navigation servitude, except for wetlands.

SEC. 6. PROCEDURE. An owner must submit a written request for compensation to the agency within 180 days of receiving notice of the agency action. The agency can negotiate the compensation amount with the owner, and if an agreement is reached, the agency must promptly pay. If no agreement is reached within 180 days, the owner can choose to take further action. If no agreement is reached within 180 days, the owner may choose to take the matter to binding arbitration or seek compensation in a civil action. The arbitration procedures shall be governed by title 9, United States Code, and the award shall include attorney's fees and other arbitration costs. The agency must promptly pay any award made to the owner. An owner who does not reach an agreement with the agency within 180 days may opt for binding arbitration or pursue compensation through a civil action. The arbitration process follows title 9, United States Code, and includes attorney's fees and other costs. The agency must promptly pay any awarded amount. If the owner prevails in a civil action, they are entitled to attorney's fees, litigation costs, and interest on the compensation amount. The owner prevailing in a civil action is entitled to attorney's fees, litigation costs, and interest on compensation. Payments are sourced from the agency's annual appropriation. The agency responsible for a payment or judgment must use its annual appropriation for the payment. If the action was due to another agency's requirement, reimbursement can be sought from that agency's funds. The agency head can transfer funds if needed, and if there are insufficient funds, the agency head must seek an appropriation for the next fiscal year. SEC. 7. LIMITATION. Any payment under this Act by the United States is subject to the availability of appropriations. SEC. 8. DUTY OF NOTICE TO OWNERS. Agencies must notify property owners affected by actions limiting property use about their rights and compensation procedures under this Act. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not limit any right to compensation under the Constitution or other US laws. Payment of compensation does not grant the Federal Government any additional rights except for use limitations resulting from agency actions. The term "property" in this Act refers to land and the right to use or receive water. A use of property is considered limited by an agency action if a legal right to use the property no longer exists due to that action. The term "agency action" includes the making of a grant to a public authority conditioned upon an action by the recipient that would constitute a limitation if done directly by the agency. The term "specified regulatory law" includes certain environmental laws such as the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, the Endangered Species Act, and the Food Security Act. The term "agency" is defined in section 551 of title 5, United States Code. The specified regulatory laws include the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, the Endangered Species Act, the Food Security Act, the Reclamation Acts, and the Federal Land Policy Management Act. The term "fair market value" is defined as the most probable price at which property would change hands in a competitive market between a willing buyer and seller. The term "fair market value" is the most probable price at which property would change hands between a willing buyer and seller in a competitive market. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and any other territory of the United States. The term "law of the State" includes the law of a political subdivision. The House of Representatives passed the bill on March 3, 1995. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
